Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: There were a lot of readings so about 2-3hr a week
2-3 hours/week
Initially 4, towards the end, barely any
Approximately 4 to 6  hours per week.
2-3 hours/week
5-10 hours

Should "required readings" have been done, ~5hrs/lecture x2 = 10h/week

Midterm response: ~10h
Final Op-Ed: ~10h
5-10 hours per week

This course brought up very interesting topics and allow for some good conversation. It wasn't the most organized. The powerpoints weren't refined and had a lot of typos throughout. The group discussions were fun, and towards the end of the course, they became more structured which was good.

interesting topics
liked the group design -- different perspectives in each group and stuck with the same groups throughout the summer session

Adam is an enthusiastic TA

There was no way to know where you stood with your understanding... it was a very passive class. Just sit and discuss. No real grading, etc.
Lack of clarity and direction throughout coursework
good

the course was overall good. I wish the readings were discussed more in class for students who don't have background in social sciences/social and behavioral health. some readings were difficult to interact with and some context from class would've been beneficial for me. the learning environment was excellent and dr ransom did a great job including a variety of perspectives on each topic and ensuring nobody felt left out (sometimes to fault of not finishing some in class material).
Really important concepts.  As we provided in the mid-term feedback, connecting the dots between the lecture's discussion and the "right answer" would be helpful.
Reading is a little excessive for the course. Stopped reading the articles after a while because everything was covered in the lecture.

Strength: really interesting topics for class discussions and small-group discussions
Weaknesses: readings could be condensed to focus on the topic for the class

The course material is very interesting and thought provoking. I would have preferred more structured feedback during class discussion and more structured learning outcomes - this was improved upon in the second half of the course after initial feedback was given.
Improvement could be made with timeliness of feedback, it would have been beneficial to receive midterm assignment grading prior to completing the final assignment.

While the content of this course was valuable, the structure in which it was presented wasn't clear and often left me feeling more confused. I wish the instructor had been more organized with how the material was presented and presented a framework in its entirety before encouraging students to discuss. I often felt that I was asked to discuss concepts I didn't fully understand.
Lack of structure and clarity on expectations.
Main strength was improvement after our mid-point feedback and TF's leading discussion. Main weakness was early disorganization.

The content of the course is great, I feel that there needs to be more structure to each lesson, ie clear learning objectives, I feel that the lecture slides could be improved to be more structured. The pre-reading- I tried to read all the material initially but it just became too overwhelming and time consuming, I feel it would be better to pick one or two key readings to focus on, and draw from that material in the lectures. One week there was over 100 pages of pre-reading and combined with my other courses there was just no way I as realistically going to get through it, so I gave up. It seems like a missed opportunity as I am genuinely interested in the subject. I feel like it's not fair to ask us to do course work, then give us no feedback during the course. If it is a 'formative' assessment ie aiding in our learning, we need feedback to be able to develop our knowledge and arguments for the subsequent assessments.

covered very interesting and complex issues and materials. 
I would suggest providing more concrete definitions in class to some of the terminologies and concepts

This is a game changing/perspective changing course.  It causes a shift in thinking and how we view others and delivery of healthcare.   It is important to the psyche of any public health administrator.

The course topics are excellent but are vague at the same time. The course can be made more concrete rather than giving us tonnes of study materials! Very good group discussions though. Both the professor and the TA seem to be working hard to make this happen!

Strengths: very interesting content, especially for people who don't have a strong public health background
Weaknesses: there was not much structure and assignments were not graded in a timely manner
In general, the content of the course was interesting, but the course's structure could be improved. In particular, I think the group projects could be eliminated.

The course helped me to think about the health related problems from a different perspective. I realized that my critical thinking improved and I interpret the news/articles that I read/hear more comprehensive now compared to the beginning of summer.
Extremely interesting discussions and issues covered, but could have used a bit more structure / foundational background.

Strengths: first and foremost, TF Adam Viera was INCREDIBLE; course covered many different aspects of SDH, Professor Ransome made incredible efforts at incorporating student feedback during the mid-point to improve the course.

Weaknesses: initially lack of clear guidelines in group activities (quickly resolved), focused excessively on professor's research related to HIV
- Recommendations: consider exploring the copious amounts of available research (as in the last few lectures) regarding topics unrelated to HIV; consider reducing the number of readings from the ~80-100pgs/week or tying them more directly to the lecture material; enjoyed posting lecture notes prior to lecture, leaving it up to students to take additional notes on the material during lecture

I really enjoyed this class. The topics discussed were interesting and really opened my eyes to the disparities in healthcare between minority groups. It has further strengthened my resolve to help all those in my community and bring healthcare equity to all. My favorite part of the class was the group exercises where we were paired with our classmates to solve issues in public health. It was very helpful to see these issues through the eyes of those with different backgrounds and to work together towards a common goal.

This was a fantastic course that comprehensively covered different core concepts in social and behavioral health such as research methods, research interpretation, types of bias in research, paradoxical results from well-intended investments

Very interesting content delivered well. Sometimes found it difficult to ascertain what exactly I was meant to be taking home from lectures in a concrete fashion - I feel like I developed a broad understanding of the course content generally but not quite an in depth understanding.

Strengths: Prompts you to think about risk factors for health outcomes in a new way
Weaknesses: Extremely disorganized flow of material. Depth in each topic was not sufficient. Instructor did not provide concrete takeaways, explained material poorly.

He was very responsive to feedback during the course. This was his first time teaching it, so it's understandable that not everything is completely organized. As he started incorporating the feedback, he became significantly better.
Passionate about material and flexible, could improve on explaining and defining concepts
good

Dr Ransome did a nice job. He clearly cares about the material and presented it in a logical way. It would be nice to know the flow of the lectures beforehand. Since we didn't have the slides before it made it a little tough to take notes in context of discussion points from class. He was very good at including everyone's thoughts and opinions however this made class go very slowly in the beginning weeks.
He's funny, thoughtful and receptive to feedback.
Continue to take feedback and improve the course. The class definitely got better after the halfway mark. Take students' comments into consideration during the discussion.

Professor Ransome asked for our feedback and incorporated it into his teaching style which I appreciated! I think he will continue to improve his teaching style. He's very eager to teach and is very knowledgable. I think he can improve class discussions by guiding the conversation and bringing it back when it starts to go off topic.

The instructor is very good at delivering thought provoking material and encouraging class discussion, I feel improvement could be made in presenting material in a more structured way with clear learning outcomes for each lecture.

Dr. Ransome was clearly very passionate about this subject but I felt that his delivery wasn't as organized as it could have been. I think an easier approach would be to introduce a concept, fully flesh it out, and then point out exceptions (rather than exploring all possible ways in which a concept can apply without clearly defining it).
Very personable. Pleasant to interact with. Interested in promoting student learning.
Very kind, but uninspiring.

Made big improvement. Would recommend only discussing his own research very rarely. Also, these concepts are v difficult so instead of saying "it depends" and uploading 1000's of articles on canvas, maybe use a basic textbook or classic examples (like Camera Jone's TED talk) to teach. Really appreciated 2nd 1/2 of class when Yusuf utilized videos and improved slides quite a bit. Think that after working out roadbumps will be a v good prof.

Very kind and approachable and has a nice lecturing style. It was good to hear about his work with HIV as examples for some of the concepts.

If could bring a bit more structure to the course I think that would help, but I understand it was his first time lecturing for this course.


Overall I enjoyed the course but I found it a bit vague and unstructured compared to other courses I have taken in the past.
Good first attempt.

Dr. Ransome was excellent.  His Socratic method of teaching in hind sight makes more sense, than when you are going through it.  He is highly knowledgeable and relatable as a teacher.  Considering that the format of this course was new, and that this was Dr. Ransome's first time teaching this course, he should be complemented for pulling it all together in such an effective manner.

Yusuf comes to the class full of energy and encouragement for discussions which makes this class unique. However, lack of formal structure of the course contents makes this task challenging! He does provide loads of reading materials though, some of which are not possible to finish reading in time!

Strengths: very energetic and engaging, you can see his passion for the material
Weaknesses: providing more concrete definitions and background for the material discussed/presented in class

Unfortunately, I could tell this was Professor Ransome's first course and believe he has great room for improvement. Sometimes, he delays answering questions in class and did not always explain concepts in a way I could understand. It also would have been helpful to receive feedback for our midterm prior to completing the final exam.
He is great, very kind and willing to teach. My only criticism is, it would be better if he updates the files/documents a little bit faster.
Yusuf was effective at facilitating interesting discussions but providing more intro background on issues could have been helpful.

Strengths: truly incorporated student feedback to improve upon the course
- admirably tackled large SBS topics instead of shying away from them

Weaknesses: heavily focused on his personal HIV research to the exclusion of many other available research on other health-related topics
- lack of timely return of midterm, resulting in no available grades prior to the end of the semester.
The instructor was very knowledgeable in his field and very enthusiastic. It was a pleasure to learn from him as someone who is actively studying the topics he was teaching.

Yusuf was fantastic.  He will be an asset to the university.  He is knowledgeable, knows how to elicit quality class discussions, and does a great job steering group conversations so we meet our peers better and learn about different perspectives to solving problems

I thoroughly enjoyed attending Professor Ransome's lectures. He made a lot of effort to ensure that the course content was interesting and relevant. He openly admitted that this was his first time teaching this class and was very receptive to feedback and tried to change things for the second half of term to make things better. Class discussions were very interesting, I feel he could maybe be slightly better at giving feedback to answers during them though. I appreciate his efforts to make the learning environment feel very comfortable for everyone - which it definitely was - but often he would take several answers at once and we would get feedback that we were all correct. This sometimes added a little bit to the ambiguity of not being concrete on what I felt I needed to know from the course but also may just be reflective of the nature of the field. His research is strongly HIV orientated and whilst this was very interesting and I genuinely enjoyed hearing about his experiences in both London and the US, I would have appreciated a little bit less of a focus on HIV related and more general content. Group exercises were also engaging if sometimes a little unclear in the early stages, and often we didn't have as much time as I would have liked. Not necessarily Professor Ransome's fault, just a feature of our limited time. Overall, a great learning experience on what was pretty much new content to me - thanks Professor!

Strengths: Knows his own research.
Weaknesses: Poor organization of the material. Slides did not make sense. Did not manage classroom well. Answered "it depends" or "yes, those are all good answers" to everything, to the point it was a joke amongst students. Also came across as defensive when students asked questions pushing for a clear answer. 
Opportunities for improvement: Structure course material and associated slides better. Have clear takeaways for each section. Give greater context before asking students to work in smaller groups on a vaguely defined problem. Integrate the readings into the classroom discussion.

This course brings up very important topics that are not talked about enough. It taught the terminology needed to discuss these topics in a more mature manner. I'm not a fan of social studies, but it does a good job highlighting important topics.
No
good
I think everyone at Yale should take an intro SBS course - this type of thinking would change the world if more people were informed.
Good overview course with a broad scope of topics. But I think it would be helpful to get our midterm grades/comments back earlier.

Very interesting material, course instructors who encourage class discussion and participation. I would recommend it to others however I would recommend that they ask for feedback throughout the course.
Basic review of SBS that fell short of my advocacy track curricula at med school. Would not recommend unless serious revisions are made including more formal curricula.
I would recommend

This is an excellent course for anyone interested in public health, I really enjoyed it.  It is eye opening and perspective changing.  It is a must for any individual who plans on being involved in healthcare.   Dr. Ransome was excellent.    I believe this course should be offered in other program manjors, because it is so important.
Really thought-provoking topics and critical analysis of determinants of health. But lack of content details is a challenge!
This is a great overview class for people who are new to public health, but it feels like a majority of the learning/appreciation for the material comes from the midterm/final assignments.
I would not recommend this course to another student.
The course gives a basic background about the determinants of health and makes you aware of the terminology and the concepts.
Great course that covers essential issues facing our world regarding health and inequality.
I would highly recommend this class as the topics are essential for anyone studying public health and the instructor was great!

This is a great course.  It's a nice contrast to the more mathematical and technical courses.  It adds a lot of perspective from a social science standpoint that helps humanize the discipline and steer our perspectives.
Overall, I really enjoyed this class and would recommend it for the reasons above.
Not recommended. Did not feel like I walked away with much. I really love this content, but do not believe it was taught well.
